componenttextpreview: This is Ashwin in behalf of Rod. I wanted to ask about the enterprise weakness that you're seeing in what [indiscernible]. So do you think it's all given the same macro weakness? Or on an EMC today, that you talked about how does seem customers all seem s
componenttext: This is Ashwin in behalf of Rod. I wanted to ask about the enterprise weakness that you're seeing in what [indiscernible]. So do you think it's all given the same macro weakness? Or on an EMC today, that you talked about how does seem customers all seem spending as you look at the [indiscernible] cloud architectures? Do you see some of that, too? And I was also wondering if you expect, if you think that customers are forcing spending ahead of your upcoming product weakness?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. Yes, so pretty much similar to what we said last quarter. In other words, we do see macro. We don't think it's a strong spending environment in general out there. But we are also, in our opinion, we think there are delays in spending caused by
componenttext: Yes, okay. Yes, so pretty much similar to what we said last quarter. In other words, we do see macro. We don't think it's a strong spending environment in general out there. But we are also, in our opinion, we think there are delays in spending caused by customers effectively strategizing over newer cloud architectures and WAP applications it should take and basically planning that. So I think we're seeing some cloud, some slowness because of the transformation in architecture. So that's 2 reasons. I must admit that I think there's another reason. I mean, over time, we've seen some disruption. And it's been well-publicized in management. I think that's behind us now. I talked about some of the hiring that John the literal in particular has done over the last few quarters and back in charge in North America and it feels really good about that. But it's -- the 2 big ones for us are really the you had macro combined with the factor that the cloud architectures and you can buy those 2 together and they make it easy to make a delay in our spending decision. And then in terms of the Osbourne type question that you asked about. Not really. I can't say we're seeing much about. We're watching that like a hawk, especially of this quarter, because I did say that the big product shipments, which is the shuttle series, is now destined for July. So I'm feeling good about really getting a good data out this pretty soon. And I think it's going to be okay with that, but we're watching it very, very closely.

componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Karl. Real quick, there's a few things. One is, typically, we -- every time we release new appliances, the new generation tends to be, on average, about 2 to 4x faster for the equivalent price points. And so we certainly are moving forward i
componenttext: Matt, this is Karl. Real quick, there's a few things. One is, typically, we -- every time we release new appliances, the new generation tends to be, on average, about 2 to 4x faster for the equivalent price points. And so we certainly are moving forward in that direction with these. All of these appliance are also now support FPGs all the way down the line up. And so as John mentioned in his script, we're going to be supporting these use case driven versions of these FPGAs for specific scenarios like security rather areas where we can optimize the platform depending on the -- how you're going to use it. So for example, with security, if you want to block, say, IP address, you can do the hardware. So we can -- or for like private cloud scenarios and data centers, you'll be able to connect things transparently to the hardware versus doing it through the having the balance CPUs. So you guys not only benefits from just the back end horsepower, but also from the ability to offload a lot of functionality into the hardware and your appliance.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also, the performance improvement, you get more modules on a single system that you would normally get. So there's a bunch of the ASA. But I actually think the big one, and that's why I said, it's not up product line upgrade because we're going to get
componenttext: And also, the performance improvement, you get more modules on a single system that you would normally get. So there's a bunch of the ASA. But I actually think the big one, and that's why I said, it's not up product line upgrade because we're going to get all that good stuff. And hopefully, the customers will benefit from the savings that we get. But more importantly is this bridge, we see as a bridge between their existing on-premise architectures and the cloud with some of the stuff that we can do that Karl mentioned on FPGAs to tunnel connectivity between private and public clouds and these products.

componenttext: No, we're offloading it from the CPUs. So we're not having to burn CPU cycles. So you can do anything in software, but it's a question of performance. And by offloading certain functionality into the hardware of the system, you can really heavily optimize this. And by the way, this is -- if you look at Intel's approach with their acquisition of Terra, they're taking the same approach where you can allow for optimization of hardware elements, as well as software elements along the same system.

componenttext: A question for you around your roadmap focus. I'd like to better understand the focus and emphasis of the roadmap. Is it on speeds and fees like you just mentioned the 100 gig VIPRION blade? Or would it be in security, for example, some of the growth opportunities in security, outgoing firewall, 10 point security is on the? I think where I'm coming from I want to better understand over the next few years, do you see a primarily as a security company or do you see primarily as an ATC company?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is an easy question. So first of all, by a mile, the focus is on more sophistication in features says within the software. That's obviously the way things are going. And especially by a long way, security being the main focus for us. So things like b
componenttext: This is an easy question. So first of all, by a mile, the focus is on more sophistication in features says within the software. That's obviously the way things are going. And especially by a long way, security being the main focus for us. So things like behavior analysis. It is like that where you'll see enhancing all our software capability. Our goal has always been to add features to increase the addressable market, especially in security. And that's where you're going to see. Speeds and fees are great because they tend to be pretty tactical from a growth perspective and we'll take advantage of that. So over time, what we are interested in is building our security portfolio that's absolutely focused on our skill set, which is application security, and then increasing that. Increasing it not just by functionality, but also, by the way, we take it to market, like for example, silverline services, cloud based and then of course, putting that software on the public clouds as well.

componenttext: Yes, just to add to that. Just given an example. Performance and functionality are critical because we use the GI firewall, for example. We're able to get the -- one of the reasons we're able to get in it was that we can replace racks of gear with a much smaller footprint, with a much higher TCO. So the performance has to be there, the functionality has to be there, but those 2 are hand-in-hand.

componenttext: Yes, as I mentioned, telco -- I mentioned the 2 verticals, telco and finance. I did say telco was doing more. We're seeing it so many times. And the really big one was, like you mentioning it, it was 2013 in the same quarter where we saw telco slump pretty badly. There's definitely -- I think it is slow spending environment in telco last quarter. I think the CNAP from some of our peers, the announcements that they made. They also, I'd say there's some slowness related to some of the decisions they're making from an NFV architecture perspective. Having said all that, I -- we look at the interest level in the 100 gig blade and it's very high. Now we're not announcing. We're not shipping it until May. We have taken fairly sizable order already, and we expect to meet revenue this quarter. So I think, to be frank, I think the biggest -- of the real run rate starts in Q4, but we will see additional revenue. And that, I think, will help certainly in the short term and beginning of 2017, the telco vertical. But apart from that, I don't think there's anything systemic. It's all about with us typically projects not closing or moving from one quarter to another.

But you do see sequential growth implied in this coming quarter, and that's our absolute focus. And that's why we're spending a lot of time talking about the new products coming out and the impact we think that's going to have through the rest of the year and into 2017. So we'll see.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions for me. First following up on Sanjiv's question on the service provider. John, is there potential, any pause here in front of your 100 gig introduction? And can you tell us if there's been some unusual turnover in your sales force in
componenttext: A couple of questions for me. First following up on Sanjiv's question on the service provider. John, is there potential, any pause here in front of your 100 gig introduction? And can you tell us if there's been some unusual turnover in your sales force in general and maybe in your service provider salesforce more specifically? And then, Andy, with regard to OpEx, I think, in your Investor Day last year, you've kind of talked about how you expect operating margins in the second half of the year to be better than the first half of the year clearly showing. But can you give us a little bit sense of magnitude how much of an improvement? Should we see a little bit more flattish pattern from your R&D expenses, which have been moving up quite aggressively in the last 3 quarters. Is that now here to how much of a lift we're getting operating margin wise?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okey-dokey. I'll take the first 2 then. On the delay. I mean, it's always tough to detail that. There may be some portion of delay that happened last quarter. Remember, we're spending a lot of time talking to the large customers, large service provider cu
componenttext: Okey-dokey. I'll take the first 2 then. On the delay. I mean, it's always tough to detail that. There may be some portion of delay that happened last quarter. Remember, we're spending a lot of time talking to the large customers, large service provider customers, about the 100 gig. We've got a pretty good view into the potential demand, both this quarter and next. As with any new product, we will try out, which is why I was indicating that we'll probably see a stronger reception to it in Q4 because it's only going to be coming out in May. But we feel really, really positive about seeing revenues in coming quarters as well. It's difficult to actually measure that type of question. I would probably say that because it's going to be available this quarter, one cancels out the other. Another one, I don't think there's any significant related costs of that 100 gig, just to be specific. Regarding the turnover question. We don't really talk about that stuff much, but I will comment on it. We did see some turnover last quarter in the Americas. We're addressing that aggressively. In fact, we have addressed most of it aggressively actually to make sure we don't lose any momentum because of that. But I won't go it in any more detail than that.

componenttext: Okay, let me take the second one first. I think, first of all, typically, when we penetrate, say, the times 200, that's a good thing because that means we do more and more business. So we love the concept of penetrating into existing customers. There's so many applications of that we can sit in front of and optimize. I don't think it's really that. I think they've been executing well in a tough environment, obviously, but they've been executing well and those environs. We think with the changes we've been making that in sales in the Americas, they're going to see similar execution coming in the future as well.

componenttextpreview: Well, yes, on the linearity, there wasn't a massive change from the norm. What we did see about that and I commented on was that we felt better about the visibility in March. In other words, by visibility, what I'm talking about is we look at -- when look
componenttext: Well, yes, on the linearity, there wasn't a massive change from the norm. What we did see about that and I commented on was that we felt better about the visibility in March. In other words, by visibility, what I'm talking about is we look at -- when looking at the pipeline in merely the forecasted deals for that quarter, and the visibility of that improved quite radically over the previous 2 quarters. We felt -- that's a combination probably of macro, but also of good sales management to make sure that we know what's going on. But the that -- and that's important to us. So not -- I wouldn't say -- I wouldn't put too much on the leading charity thing because it was it might be different from what we expect. It was a little bit soft in January and February, and we were a bit worried about visibility. In other words, we thought we do without all the better than we do. But we came to merge, and we felt that the split was excellent. So that's on -- oh, yes, the AWS and the cloud and that question. I mean, I realized that a lot of concern we just got this stuff a lot internally. But when we look at the installed base and the customers heavy opportunities, we see a lot with things like our WAP product, our APM product that actually get 3 examples in fact, of that type of thing. So there are definitely opportunities there as well. But we've seen new business opportunities where a fairly big companies where we had no presence and we managed to get into that company via AWS marketplace interestingly enough. And obviously, we feel good about this whole hybrid side of things, especially maybe more and more focused orchestration in areas like that. Having said all that, I do still think that it's actually causing delay in spending overall. We also see some partnership ops -- opportunities with companies like Microsoft and Amazon, or AWS, in terms of working with them on enterprise customers. And we had one very good example of that, that I mentioned the banking company, where that was an example of a partnership. Yes, I think it's early days. I mean, it's not that we -- we don't look at the pipeline right now and say, oh, my God, this is shrinking because of Amazon we don't see that or because of the public cloud. And there's no doubt in my mind, we probably don't get some business that we've got before of a start-up company that will go straight to the public cloud and maybe just instead of buying equipment just ran some software that software could well be ours. But it's not critical. yes, the major concern it gives us right now is it is it going daily and from an opportunity perspective, how can we maximize our product on those public clouds and by partnering with a very the cloud vendors.

componenttextpreview: And then, Paul, you were asking about the Virtual Editions in the pricing. And essentially, at our entry-level, hardware systems, you do see parity on the gross margin dollar still. So it's not quite the same price wise, but it's equivalent on the gross m
componenttext: And then, Paul, you were asking about the Virtual Editions in the pricing. And essentially, at our entry-level, hardware systems, you do see parity on the gross margin dollar still. So it's not quite the same price wise, but it's equivalent on the gross margin dollars. And we're still seeing that deal sizes aren't necessarily smaller because usually, when they're buying Virtual Editions, they're deploying them on a more horizontal type of architecture. So they need more versions of it. So we're still in that kind of position. In some of the things that I'd highlight the was we're looking a new licensing model specifically for the cloud. So bring your own license or you can take VE and move it as you want to. An enterprise license agreements. If they want a license in large scale, we'll do an enterprise license agreement. And I think where we're coming at with a 40 gig VE and an FF environment, you might see that as well, where we do a lot of larger to enterprise type licensing agreements, and then we'll see how that works out at discounting. And then we do offer on a utility basis, on AWS, the ability to pull out your credit card and license our Virtual Editions. So we'll continue to be looking at those business models to evolve them to the needs of our customers.

Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks Second Quarter and Fiscal 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. If anyone has any objections, please disconnect at this time.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sam. Welcome, everyone, to our conference call for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. John McAdam, our President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. The other members of our exec team are also
componenttext:
Thank you, Sam. Welcome, everyone, to our conference call for the second quarter of fiscal 2016. John McAdam, our President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. The other members of our exec team are also on hand to answer questions following John and Andy's prepared comments. If you have any follow-up questions, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571.
A copy of today's press release is available on our website at f5.com. In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast from the Events Calendar page of our website through July 20. At 4:30 p.m. today until midnight Pacific Time, April 21, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (866) 474-1441 or (203) 369-1499.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements, which include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve uncertainties and risks that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements. Factors that may affect our results are summarized in our quarterly release and described in detail in our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. In a relatively challenging environment, F5 delivered year-over-year revenue growth and strong profitability. Revenue in Q2 grew 2.4% year-over-year to $483.7 million within our guided range of $480 million to $490 million. Non-GAAP earni
componenttext:
Thank you, John. In a relatively challenging environment, F5 delivered year-over-year revenue growth and strong profitability. Revenue in Q2 grew 2.4% year-over-year to $483.7 million within our guided range of $480 million to $490 million. Non-GAAP earnings per share were $1.68, above our guided range of $1.61 to $1.64 per share. These results exceeded our forecast, driven by strength in gross margins and prudent management of expenses as well as a decrease to our worldwide effective tax rate and the strong buyback of our common stock.
GAAP EPS of $1.11 per share was below our guidance of $1.13 to $1.16 per share due to onetime costs for a patent-related jury verdict and other costs associated with that litigation. The related impact of these onetime costs to GAAP EPS was approximately $0.08. Product revenue of $225.4 million declined 4% sequentially and 8% year-over-year and represented 47% of total revenue. Service revenue of $258.2 million increased 1% sequentially, 13% year-over-year and accounted for 53% of total revenue.
Revenue from the Americas accounted for 56% of total revenue during the quarter; EMEA contributed 25%; APAC 13%; and Japan 5%. On a year-over-year basis, the Americas were up 1%; EMEA revenue was up 8%; APAC revenue grew 1%; and Japan revenue was down 1%. 
Enterprise customers represented 64% of total sales during the quarter. Service providers accounted for 21% and government sales were 16%, including 7% of total sales from U.S. federal. 
In Q2, we have 3 greater than 10% distributors: Westcon, which accounted for 18.2% of total revenue; Ingram Micro, which represented 15% of total revenue; and Avnet representing 13.3%. Our GAAP gross margin in Q2 was 83%. Our non-GAAP gross margin was 84.6%. 
Including $8.9 million for patent-related jury verdict and other costs associated with that litigation, GAAP operating expenses were $286.5 million, above our guided range of $272 million to $281 million. Non-GAAP operating expenses, which exclude these patent litigation costs as well as stock-based compensation and amortization of purchased intangible assets, were $239.8 million. GAAP operating margin was 23.8%. Our non-GAAP operating margin was 35%. Our GAAP effective tax rate for Q2 was 34.5%. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 32.7%.
Turning to the balance sheet. Cash flow from operations was $133.1 million. In Q2, we repurchased 2.1 million shares of our common stock at an average price of $94.62 for a total of $200 million, ending the quarter with approximately $1.1 billion in cash and investments. At its April meeting, the Board approved an additional share repurchase authorization of up to $1 billion. 
DSO at the end of Q2 was 50 days. Inventories were $35.2 million. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $16.5 million. Deferred revenue increased 17% year-over-year to $842.7 million. And we ended the quarter with approximately 4,325 employees, an increase of 50 from the prior quarter.
Onto our fiscal Q3 outlook. As we enter into the historically stronger second half of our fiscal year, we remain focused on business execution and the delivery of our upcoming new products and features to drive the next leg of growth for F5. With this in mind, our revenue target for the third quarter of fiscal 2016 is $490 million to $500 million. GAAP gross margin is anticipated to be in the 82.5% range, including approximately $4.5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2.7 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. 
Non-GAAP gross margin is expected to be at or around 84%. We anticipate GAAP operating expenses in the range of $270 million to $279 million. This includes approximately $36.5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $0.8 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets. For Q3, we are forecasting a GAAP effective tax rate of 35% and a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 33%.
Our GAAP EPS target is $1.29 to $1.32 per share. Our non-GAAP EPS target is $1.77 to $1.80 per share. We plan to increase our headcount by up to 50 employees in the current quarter, and we believe our cash flow from operations will be at or around $155 million. With that, I will turn the call over to John McAdam.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, I was pleased with the F5 team's fiscal Q2 performance. We delivered year-over-year revenue growth of 2.4%, with strong profitability and operating margins in a relatively challenging business environme
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, I was pleased with the F5 team's fiscal Q2 performance. We delivered year-over-year revenue growth of 2.4%, with strong profitability and operating margins in a relatively challenging business environment. 
From a sales perspective, EMEA, Japan and our Asia Pacific region all delivered year-over-year sales bookings growth. Sales bookings in our America region were down year-over-year in Q2 as we experienced a drop in sales in our 2 strongest verticals, finance and telco. 
However, in spite of the shortfall in these verticals, sales from large transactions remained solid in the Americas during the quarter, with year-over-year growth from sales in the $1 million plus category. Our services business continues to deliver strong results and excellent profitability, with year-over-year revenue growth of 13%. Also, deferred revenue grew 17% year-over-year in the quarter, which should bode well for future business. 
Our good/better/best pricing models continues to be a significant percentage of our bookings, with year-over-year growth of 25%. As in previous quarters, customer adoption of the best category remains very strong. 
Overall, software revenue also remained strong in Q2, with more than 1/3 of the product revenue coming from software sales, driven by security module sales; GBB and software-only VE solutions. Security continues to be the growth driver of our business. We had a number of excellent wins last quarter, driven by our application security modules, with strong year-over-year growth in large transactions. 
For example, a global Fortune 25 company invested almost $1 million in the F5 APM solution to enable identity and access management for their employees into the Microsoft Office 365 environment. Also, we won a project with a U.S. regional airline, who invested nearly $1 million in our on-premise Web application firewall to help mitigate malicious and organic DDoS-oriented service interruptions. 
Another example was with a telco provider with more than 20 million subscribers, which made a significant investment in Silverline anti-DDoS services to thwart attacks orchestrated by an unidentified activist. 
We delivered solid sequential and year-over-year growth from Silverline, our cloud-based subscription DDOS and WAP security services. The pipeline for Silverline services continues to grow, and we continue to invest in additional headcount in sales and support resources to take advantage of this growth opportunity. 
We also launched an inside initiative in Q2 targeting the midrange market opportunity where there is real need for application and DDoS protection ideally suited to a subscription service model. We also had some excellent wins in the hybrid private and public cloud environments. A large European banking customer purchased over several hundred thousand dollars of VE subscription licenses through the AWS Marketplace for the deployment of a new customer engagement portal that coexist with the existing infrastructure and will ultimately support more than 10 million customers. 
A large SaaS customer invested in VE license through the AWS Marketplace to provision Layer 7 local traffic management capabilities on a new platform as a service offering to an installed base. Another cloud win last quarter involves a large U.S.-based entertainment content provider purchasing VE licenses through the AWS Marketplace as part of the lift and shift strategy to move their customer interaction operations into the public cloud. 
As far as the outlook is concerned, Andy indicated that we expect to deliver revenue in the range of $490 million to $500 million. In the context of several global macroeconomic issues, we delivered solid financial results in Q2. But as we stated last quarter, we believe it is prudent to remain cautious in the short term. 
We have made good progress in all our strategic and major initiatives in Q2. As I mentioned last quarter, we have no shortage of short-term business drivers, which we will introduce starting this current quarter. Earlier this month, we introduced a new version of TMOS, version 12.1, known internally as a cascade release. Cascade supports a new 100-gig blade for high-end VIPRION series, which I will talk about shortly. Cascade also make huge strides to increase F5's leadership in application programmability and application deployment. 
Cascade introduces F5's next-generation iRules and iApp functionality called iRules LX and iApps LX. IRules LX allows users to leverage no. GS libraries to provide new functionality addressing the needs of the Dev Ops market as well as customer applications that need customization and programmability. 
IRules LX is based on the Linerate technology and is fully integrated into TMOS. IApps LX allows for easy programming of specific use cases for application services, leveraging the broadly used Web application programming language, JavaScript. IApps LX also significantly enhances the F5 orchestration and SDN products, as it allows use cases to be dynamically published via BIG-IQ into the various SDN controllers, such as the Cisco, APEC, VMware NSX and OpenStack. This is a really unique feature, which should give F5 a clear advantage with our SDN partners. We are on track to deliver a new performance FIPS appliance and LME based on the BIG-IP 10K series appliances. It uses next generation technology, enabling an 8x improvement in the SSL performance of existing solutions. This product is designed to address core requirements in both our financial services and the federal markets. 
We successfully demonstrated our 100-gig blade for the high-end VIPRION series platform at Mobile World Congress last quarter. The new VIPRION 100-gig interfaces more than doubles the performance of the existing cards, thereby enabling the first-ever terabit-class ADC in the market. We are seeing strong interest in the 100-gig blade from our global service providers and have already received an initial $1 million plus order for the product. The 100-gig blade is on track for delivery in May, and we would expect to see initial revenues from the 100-gig blade this quarter can come in Q3, with growing momentum in Q4 and into fiscal 2017.
The new blade runs all TMOS application modules and is targeted at service provider applications, including our Gi firewall, Carrier-Grade NAT and intelligent traffic steering. BIG-IQ release 5 is also on track for release this quarter, and we are very encouraged by the customer reaction to the new functionality and scalability improvement that are included in the release. 
Release 5 includes centralized management for all security products, including APM, ASM, AFM, Gi firewall and WebSafe antifraud. It also adds new device management capabilities, ADC management and application analytics. I mentioned in last quarter's call that we plan to expand our product portfolio by adding purpose-built security products, which will address new markets. The initial release will include an SSL intercept and SSL air gap solution as well as stand-alone -- as well as a stand-alone DDoS solution, with new behavioral and threat intelligence capabilities. There have been some small changes in the delivery schedule for these 2 products. The initial release of the SSL intercept and air gap products will now be available in early July and the stand-alone DDoS products should be available slightly earlier-than-expected with availability towards the end of this current quarter. 
It's worth noting that we have already 1 large SSL intercept project using our existing iRules on our current ADC range of products. The initial version of the stand-alone SSL intercept solution will use our existing iApp technology to allow a much simpler implementation. This will then be enhanced further by using the new iApp LX functionality in the later release. 
We're also making good progress to release a 40-gig capable version of our software VE solution. Intel demonstrated our F5 VE solution in 100-gig environment at Mobile World Congress and received a lot of interest from service providers, who have the goal of driving NFV architectures in the future. 
Progress on our plan to deliver a comprehensive appliance refresh is going well. And we are on track to commence delivery of the new products in July and have all products available within a 3 to 4-month window. The new appliances known internally as the shuttle series significantly improve performance, decrease total cost of ownership and increase our competitive leadership. However, the shuttle series is much more than a simple product line upgrade. The shuttle series is Dev Ops friendly and encompasses a full stack of security solutions and offer specific persona-based customized solutions using our proprietary FPGA software-defined hardware functionality. The shuttle series will support our application modules across entire product lineup and are designed to support and enable [indiscernible] architectures, including hybrid clouds. 
Our higher level goal with the shuttle series is to bridge the gap between traditional IT, the Dev Ops environments and the emerging cloud architecture. I continue to believe F5 is in a really strong position to take advantage of industry trends and customer requirements. Our absolute focus is on execution with a primary goal of delivering product revenue growth. And I believe this goal will be achieved as we deliver the new product business drivers to the market. 
We have added several key executives to the F5 team last quarter to support and enhance our focus on execution. You may have seen recent press releases announcing the appointment of key sales and security executives to F5. I am really excited to have Pete Brant, David Helfer and Mike Convertino in the F5 team. Pete joins us as SVP for North American sales and brings with him a fantastic track record with more than 20 years of experience in technology and security sales. David joins us as VP of Worldwide Channels and brings extensive experience in global channels and sales operation, again with a fantastic track record. Mike is F5's first Chief Information Security Officer. His first priority is continued protection of the company's customer assets and data. Mike will also play a lead role in the development of F5 security products -- securities product roadmap and represent F5 in the IT industry and wider security community. 
In conclusion, I would like to thank the entire F5 team, our partners and customers for their support last quarter. And with that, we'll hand the call over to Q&A.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is AK [ph] on behalf of Rod. I wanted to ask about the enterprise spending weakness that you're seeing and what's driving that. So do you think it's all driven by the same macro weakness? Or on an EMC today, earlier today, talked about how they're se
componenttext: This is AK [ph] on behalf of Rod. I wanted to ask about the enterprise spending weakness that you're seeing and what's driving that. So do you think it's all driven by the same macro weakness? Or on an EMC today, earlier today, talked about how they're seeing customers pausing spending as they look at the various different cloud architectures? Do you see some of that too? And I was also wondering if you expect, if you think that customers are pausing spending ahead of your upcoming product weakness?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. Yes, so pretty much similar to what we said last quarter. In other words, we do see macro. We don't think it's a strong spending environment in general idea. But we are also -- in our opinion, we think there are delays in spending caused by cus
componenttext: Yes, okay. Yes, so pretty much similar to what we said last quarter. In other words, we do see macro. We don't think it's a strong spending environment in general idea. But we are also -- in our opinion, we think there are delays in spending caused by customers effectively strategizing over newer cloud architectures and applications it should take and basically planning that. So I think we're seeing some slowness because of the transformation in architecture. So that's 2 reasons. I must admit that I think there's another reason. I mean, over time, we've seen some disruption. And it's been well-publicized in management. I think that's behind us now. I talked about some of the hiring that John DiLullo in particular has done over the last couple of quarters with -- some of the back in charge in North America and feel really good about that. But it's -- the 2 big ones for us are really that you had macro combined with the factor that the cloud architectures and you combine those 2 together and make easy to make a delay in the spending decision. And then in terms of the Osborne-type question that you asked about. Not really. I can't say we're seeing much of that. We're watching that like a hawk, especially this quarter, because I did see the big product shipments, which is the shuttle series, is now destined for July. So I'm feeling good about really getting a good date and that's pretty soon. And I think we're going to be okay with that, but we're watching it very, very closely.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matt Robison with Wunderlich.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matt Robison with Wunderlich.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you can elaborate a little bit more on the TCO benefits for shuttle series. I'm trying to get my arms around what's going to stimulate an installed base upgrade cycle.
componenttext: I was hoping you can elaborate a little bit more on the TCO benefits for shuttle series. I'm trying to get my arms around what's going to stimulate an installed base upgrade cycle.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Karl. Real quick, there's a few things. One is, typically, we -- every time we release new appliances, the new generation tends to be, on average, about 2 to 4x faster for the equivalent price points. And so we certainly are moving forward in that
componenttext: This is Karl. Real quick, there's a few things. One is, typically, we -- every time we release new appliances, the new generation tends to be, on average, about 2 to 4x faster for the equivalent price points. And so we certainly are moving forward in that direction with these. All of these appliances also now support FPGAs all the way down the line up. And so as John mentioned in his script, we're going to be supporting these use case driven versions of these FPGAs for specific scenarios like security or other areas, where we can optimize the platform depending on the -- how you're going to use it. So for example, with security, if you want to block, say, IP address, you can do that in the hardware or we can -- or for like private cloud scenarios and data centers, you'll be able to connect things transparently to the hardware versus doing it through the -- having the balance everything through the CPUs. So you guys not only benefit from just the back end horsepower, but also from the ability to offload a lot of functionality into the hardware and the appliance.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also, the performance improvement, you get more modules on a single system that you would normally get. So there's a bunch of the areas here. But I actually think the big one, and that's why I said, it's not just a product line upgrade, because we're
componenttext: And also, the performance improvement, you get more modules on a single system that you would normally get. So there's a bunch of the areas here. But I actually think the big one, and that's why I said, it's not just a product line upgrade, because we're going to get all that good stuff. And hopefully, the customers will benefit from the savings that they get. But more importantly, is this bridge, we see as a bridge between that existing on-premise architectures and the cloud, with some of the stuff that we can do that Karl mentioned on FPGAs to tunnel connectivity between private and public clouds and these products.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So a part of it is, when you say offload, that sounds like maybe you're pulling some wallet share from some of the adjacent types of products. I know you mentioned the SSL intercept. But are you talking about those kind of, to refresh my senses...
componenttext: Okay. So a part of it is, when you say offload, that sounds like maybe you're pulling some wallet share from some of the adjacent types of products. I know you mentioned the SSL intercept. But are you talking about those kind of, to refresh my senses...

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We're offloading it from the CPUs. So we're not having to burn CPU cycles. So you can do anything in software, but it's a question of performance. And by offloading certain functionality into the hardware of the system, you can really heavily optimize
componenttext: No. We're offloading it from the CPUs. So we're not having to burn CPU cycles. So you can do anything in software, but it's a question of performance. And by offloading certain functionality into the hardware of the system, you can really heavily optimize this. And by the way, this is -- if you look at Intel's approach with their acquisition of Altera, they're taking the same approach, where you can allow for optimization of hardware elements, as well as software elements along the same system.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're really talking about going back to what John said about running more modules on the given appliance and...
componenttext: So you're really talking about going back to what John said about running more modules on the given appliance and...

componenttext: More functionality, more modules, more consolidation more performance. The modules also -- the systems also have more memory. So we can support higher concurrency limits. There's a lot of goodness with that architecture.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the TCO comes down, they're running more modules then...
componenttext: So the TCO comes down, they're running more modules then...

componenttext: For us, that plus the other things we said.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for you around your road map focus. I'd like to better understand the focus and emphasis of the road map. Is it on speeds and feeds like you just mentioned 100-gig VIPRION blades? Or would it be in security, for example, some of the growth oppo
componenttext: A question for you around your road map focus. I'd like to better understand the focus and emphasis of the road map. Is it on speeds and feeds like you just mentioned 100-gig VIPRION blades? Or would it be in security, for example, some of the growth opportunities in security, outbound firewalls, endpoint security? I think where I'm coming from is, I want to better understand over the next few years, do you see F5 primarily as a security company or do you see it primarily as an ADC company?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is an easy question. So first of all, by a mile, the focus is on more sophistication in future sales [ph] within the software. That's obviously the way things are going. And especially, by a long way, security being the main focus for us. So things l
componenttext: This is an easy question. So first of all, by a mile, the focus is on more sophistication in future sales [ph] within the software. That's obviously the way things are going. And especially, by a long way, security being the main focus for us. So things like behavior analysis. It is like that where you'll see enhancing all our software capability. Our goal has always been to add features to increase the addressable market, especially in security. And that's where you're going to see. Speeds and feeds are great because they tend to be pretty tactical from a growth perspective and we'll take advantage of that. So over time, what we are interested in is building our security portfolio that's absolutely focused on our skill set, which is application security and then increasing that. And increasing it not just by functionality, but also, by the way, we take it to market; like for example, Silverline services, cloud based and then of course, putting that software on all the public clouds as well.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to add to that. Just giving example. Performance and functionality are critical because we use the Gi firewall, for example. We're able to get in -- one of the reasons we're able to get in there is that we can replace racks of gear with a much sm
componenttext: And just to add to that. Just giving example. Performance and functionality are critical because we use the Gi firewall, for example. We're able to get in -- one of the reasons we're able to get in there is that we can replace racks of gear with a much smaller footprint, with a much higher TCO. And so the performance has to be there, the functionality has to be there, but those 2 are hand-in-hand.

componenttext: Yes, we're happy with it. I mean, I actually is quite specific that we actually saw year-over-year sales, bookings growth in APAC and in Japan and in EMEA. We think we're executing really well there and we've got good opportunity.

componenttext: Right. And maybe my calculation might be a little bit off. But telco was down, I'm thinking in sort the mid-teens or somewhere around there.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I mentioned, telco -- I mentioned the 2 verticals, telco and finance. I did say that telco was down more. We're seeing this so many times. And the really big one was, I don't even like mentioning it, it was 2013 in the same quarter where we saw te
componenttext: Yes, as I mentioned, telco -- I mentioned the 2 verticals, telco and finance. I did say that telco was down more. We're seeing this so many times. And the really big one was, I don't even like mentioning it, it was 2013 in the same quarter where we saw telco slump pretty badly. There's definitely -- I think it is a slow spending environment in telco last quarter. I think we've seen that from some of our peers and the announcements that they have made. There also, I think there's some slowness related to some of the decisions they're making from an NFV architecture perspective. Having said all that, I -- we look at the interest level in the 100-gig blade, and it's very high. We're not announcing. We're not shipping it until May. We have taken fairly sizable order already, and we expect to meet revenue this quarter. So I think -- to be frank, I think the biggest -- the real run rate starts in Q4, but we will see additional revenue. And that, I think, will help certainly in the short term and beginning of 2017, the telco vertical. But apart from that, I don't think that's anything systemic. It's all about with us typically projects not closing or moving from one quarter to another.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then to your question on product revenue growth. I mean, obviously, we don't guide beyond the current quarter. But you do see sequential growth implied in this coming quarter, and that's our absolute focus. And that's why we're spending a lot of time
componenttext: And then to your question on product revenue growth. I mean, obviously, we don't guide beyond the current quarter. But you do see sequential growth implied in this coming quarter, and that's our absolute focus. And that's why we're spending a lot of time talking about the new products coming out and the impact we think that's going to have through the rest of the year and 2017. So we'll see.

componenttext: Our next question is from Ittai Kidron with Oppenheimer.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions from me. First following up on Sanjiv's question on the service provider. John, is there potential, any pause here in front of your 100-gig introduction? And can you tell us if there's been some unusual turnover in your sales force i
componenttext: A couple of questions from me. First following up on Sanjiv's question on the service provider. John, is there potential, any pause here in front of your 100-gig introduction? And can you tell us if there's been some unusual turnover in your sales force in general and maybe in your service provider sales force more specifically? And then, Andy, with regards to OpEx, I think in your Investor Day last year, you've kind of talked about how you expect operating margins in the second half of the year to be better than the first half of the year clearly showing. But can you give us a little bit sense of magnitude how much of an improvement? Should we see a little bit more flattish pattern from your R&D expenses, which have been moving up quite aggressively in the last 3 quarters? Does that [indiscernible] now here to how much of a lift we're getting operating margin wise?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okey-dokey. I'll take the first 2 then. On the delay. I mean, it's always tough to detail that. There may be some portion of delay that happened last quarter. Remember, we're spending a lot of time talking to the large customers, large service provider cu
componenttext: Okey-dokey. I'll take the first 2 then. On the delay. I mean, it's always tough to detail that. There may be some portion of delay that happened last quarter. Remember, we're spending a lot of time talking to the large customers, large service provider customers, about the 100 gig. We've got a pretty good view into the potential demand, both this quarter and next. As with any new product, they will try out, which is why I was indicating that we'll probably see a stronger reception to it in Q4 because it's only going to be coming out in May. But we feel really, really positive about seeing revenues this coming quarter as well. It's difficult to actually measure that type of question. I would probably say that because it's going to be available this quarter, one cancels out the other. Another was, I don't think there's going to be any significant related cause of the 100 gig, just to be specific. Regarding the turnover question. We don't really talk about that stuff much, but I will comment on it. We did see some turnover last quarter in the Americas. We're addressing that aggressively. In fact, we have addressed most of it aggressively actually to make sure that we don't lose any momentum because of that. But I wouldn't go into it any more detail than that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on operating margin, yes, the messaging we put out there still holds. And if you look at our revenue guidance against the OpEx and gross margin I put out there, we are going to see some improvement in operating margin. Like we always say, we're going
componenttext: And on operating margin, yes, the messaging we put out there still holds. And if you look at our revenue guidance against the OpEx and gross margin I put out there, we are going to see some improvement in operating margin. Like we always say, we're going to watch it against the revenue and adjust accordingly. So we're looking forward to continued improvement against revenue growth. And if we see that, we'll have it. And if not, we'll adjust accordingly.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jim Suva with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jim Suva with Citi.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It seems like in the next couple of quarters, you've got a lot of new product launches and things like that, which is very exciting, don't get me wrong. Can you help us understand about what we should be thinking about for OpEx as well as margins? I think
componenttext: It seems like in the next couple of quarters, you've got a lot of new product launches and things like that, which is very exciting, don't get me wrong. Can you help us understand about what we should be thinking about for OpEx as well as margins? I think you'd mentioned you're going to be hiring this quarter about, I think you said, 50 additional new employees, which is good. The cost profiles, the operating expenses and associated gross margins out kind of the run rate overdue now versus these newer products, so we don't get too ahead of ourselves and monitor in kind of things how they plan out with these next couple of quarters of your new product launches.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so specifically on gross margins, where we think we could see potential upside, we don't think the new products coming out will have a lower gross margin profile. This is really about mix and mix to software and the impact that could have on the long
componenttext: Yes, so specifically on gross margins, where we think we could see potential upside, we don't think the new products coming out will have a lower gross margin profile. This is really about mix and mix to software and the impact that could have on the longer-term to our margin, and we'll see. As we talk about quite a bit, if we do get gross margin improvement, we'd like to look at how we can invest that back in the business. And our most recent obvious example is bringing Silverline to market with really out much of an impact on our overall business model. So -- and though we don't guide much beyond the next quarter, where you see we said 84% for our non-GAAP gross margin, we expect to see strong gross margins continue and we'll manage it more carefully.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Mark Moskowitz with Barclays.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions, if I could. I just wanted to drill a little deeper in terms of the international strength, if you will, relative to the U.S. How much of that is related to market share gains versus just penetration of existing customers? And then the
componenttext: Two quick questions, if I could. I just wanted to drill a little deeper in terms of the international strength, if you will, relative to the U.S. How much of that is related to market share gains versus just penetration of existing customers? And then the other question we had. We've been doing some work and others have limited in terms of how many VARs we can speak with. But the VARs seem to feedback to us that, hey, a lot of our customers don't recognize F5 as a security vendor. I was just kind of curious why you're not taking advantage of this opportunity with all these new products maybe spend a little more from sales evangelism perspective to get the word out that you're going to be a long-term security vendor.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me take the second one first. I mean, we do -- we couldn't deny that we could improve our security profile image because we think we've already end it. But clearly, we haven't end it from a marketing or profile perspective, and we need to do tha
componenttext: Okay, let me take the second one first. I mean, we do -- we couldn't deny that we could improve our security profile image because we think we've already end it. But clearly, we haven't end it from a marketing or profile perspective, and we need to do that. COC is doing a number of things. I mean, if you look at some of the hires that we're hiring, we're hiring more and more security people. And we've added significant security experts within the field to support the overall sales force. We've -- I've talked about Pete Brant with his background in security. Our new [indiscernible] -- COC is doing more than that. I'm not going to say any specific spend. But it's a big focus to us because it's the future. We're also pushing ahead with the security research team as well. Because we do need to get more public about it. I mean, in fact, if you looked in the script today, we probably never really mentioned some of the security wins we've had during a call. We started to do that as well. So we do take that -- we take that input very seriously. In terms of the first question on the outside north -- outside of the Americas in terms of how the growth profile, I'm not sure it's directed at market share gain and/or customer penetration. I think, first of all, typically, when we penetrate, say, the times 200, that's a good thing because that means we do more and more business. So we love the concept of penetrating into existing customers. There's so many applications that we can sit in front and [indiscernible] optimize. I don't think it's really that. I think that they've been executing well in a tough environment, obviously, but they've been executing well in those environments. We think -- with the changes we've been making, that John DiLullo has been making in sales in the Americas, you're going to see similar execution coming in the future as well.

But is this just the beginning of a portfolio expansion in security? And then, Andy, if you could talk to the sales overlay. Are these SEs working with account managers or you're hearing dedicated account managers with security quota?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. On the first question. Yes, it's absolutely beginning, and Karl can talk about this in a second. I would say, first of all, DDoS we feel really good about across the board and you'll us linking our stand-alone DDoS solution to our Silverline DD
componenttext: Yes. Okay. On the first question. Yes, it's absolutely beginning, and Karl can talk about this in a second. I would say, first of all, DDoS we feel really good about across the board and you'll us linking our stand-alone DDoS solution to our Silverline DDoS solution via signaling, which is going to be pretty unique, and we feel good about that. But the reason I'm mentioning the first 2 is that we're hearing a lot of interest from the field on SSL intercept and SSL air gap. So yes, we will be adding more. But our main focus is going to be making -- taking that opportunity. In terms of the types of things we're adding, the shuttle series is obviously get to that and Karl might want to comment.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I was going to comment. We're significantly enhanching our security portfolio. I mean, centralized management, we didn't talk about that, but with BIG-IQ 5.0, our whole security of portfolios now managed under one central controller. We can manage mu
componenttext: Yes, I was going to comment. We're significantly enhanching our security portfolio. I mean, centralized management, we didn't talk about that, but with BIG-IQ 5.0, our whole security of portfolios now managed under one central controller. We can manage multiple hundreds of devices, tens of thousands of objects, things like that. So we're really expanding that. And then with the appliances, the SSL intercept, John mentioned the same thing with the DDoS as well as carrier-grade firewall and some other things that we're planning in the future. We're significantly enhancing the capabilities that DDoS solution in addition to that and doing things like behavioral DDoS, being able to fingerprint, identify bad actors. We can leverage that for threat intelligence feeds. We have security analytics that we're building and that will be coming out as part of the solution. We've been significantly enhancing our identity and access management solution, which is our APM platform. We're adding some major new features in the next 6 months to that to enhance its federation and single sign-on capability. So there's just a lot going on, on that portfolio that we just don't have time to talk about here [indiscernible]. But there's a tremendous amount of focus from the teams on that.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. First, with respect to the outlook and some of the macro uncertainty reference, can you comment to what extent it's anything different to be incrementally conservative in terms of developing your Q3 forecast relative to what we've seen over
componenttext: Two questions. First, with respect to the outlook and some of the macro uncertainty reference, can you comment to what extent it's anything different to be incrementally conservative in terms of developing your Q3 forecast relative to what we've seen over the last few quarters? And then, for Andy, on the new buyback authorization, I was hoping to understand how aggressively you plan to be and perhaps you can touch upon how you're thinking about M&A and to what extent we should be expecting some activity during the second half of the year as you look to bolster some of your security capabilities?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the first question, I mean, obviously, we're trying to be appropriately conservative, and I think we're managing that. Probably, if I was going to pick one thing that we're very aware of and we're looking at a forecast at the moment is the fact we've b
componenttext: On the first question, I mean, obviously, we're trying to be appropriately conservative, and I think we're managing that. Probably, if I was going to pick one thing that we're very aware of and we're looking at a forecast at the moment is the fact we've been through product transition, both good and bad. I mean, in 100 gig, we can see some upside. And we need to be careful about any Osborne effect. So we're taking a conservative view in that. That's the main areas. And then the real stuff, which is just crossing the i's and sorry, dotting the i's and crossing the t's in terms of the core business, looking at forecast, making sure we do face-to-face QBRs that type of thing.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the buyback authorization, really that's the Board teeing it up. We'll continue with our routine of every Board meeting, reviewing it. I think you've seen over the last couple of quarters, it's actually have gotten a bit more aggressive just r
componenttext: And then on the buyback authorization, really that's the Board teeing it up. We'll continue with our routine of every Board meeting, reviewing it. I think you've seen over the last couple of quarters, it's actually have gotten a bit more aggressive just relative to share price being down and not setting up a 10b5-1 that has trigger points. And do I think we're going to get more aggressive? We'll have to see on that. That's a Board decision, but we like the cadence that we're at right now. As far as M&A goes, we continue to look. I would characterize it pretty aggressively in the areas of security and telco for opportunities that we think fit, but we wouldn't comment much more than that.

componenttext: Yes, I think, last quarter, we talked about widening the lens, which I think implies that we would look at bigger deals relative to maybe what you've seen us do. But again, it's going to be something that we look at very critically because we understand the risk of that as well and we're going to look for those opportunities that are the right fit, both strategically and culturally, that we think can really drive a company forward. So I'm very focused on that outcome.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, Andy, a couple of things. One, can you offer us any color on the cloud one? Obviously, there's been a lot of concern among the investment community about your position relative to the cloud, Amazon in particular, but the cloud in general. You refere
componenttext: John, Andy, a couple of things. One, can you offer us any color on the cloud one? Obviously, there's been a lot of concern among the investment community about your position relative to the cloud, Amazon in particular, but the cloud in general. You referenced that, I believe, you referenced 2 wins in your prepared remarks. Any additional color around that -- I recognized you've been rejiggering your portfolio to optimize your cloud offerings to streamline and to get the right price points. Can you update us on where you are, how much more you need to do to get to where you want and need to be? And then a quick question for Andy. Andy, historically on Virtual Editions, I think you've referenced the fact that ASPs, you used to say they were 80% of the price point on hardware. I think more recently you referenced them as being comparable. But I think you've always said the net income impact was awash. I'm hoping you could update us. And one final question if I may, another number here. John, on the linearity issue, in your comments about enterprise demand, we had actually recently note that there was -- you saw meaningful downtick in the month of March from a number of com equipment suppliers and you've named them obviously. But and then in your comments, if I understood you correctly, the quarter started off slow coming at the last quarter in January and February and there was a pickup in March, I'm just wondering if you could shed any more light in terms of the pattern as it speaks to forward business.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the linearity, there wasn't a massive change from the norm. What we did see about that and I commented on was that we felt better about the visibility in March. In other words, by visibility, what I'm talking about is we look at -- we're looking a
componenttext: Yes, on the linearity, there wasn't a massive change from the norm. What we did see about that and I commented on was that we felt better about the visibility in March. In other words, by visibility, what I'm talking about is we look at -- we're looking at the pipeline in mainly the forecasted deals for that quarter and the visibility of that improved quite radically over the previous 2 quarters. We felt -- that's a combination probably of macro, but also of good sales management to make sure that we know what's going on. But that -- and that's important to us. So I wouldn't say -- I wouldn't put too much on the linearity thing because that was -- it wasn't widely different from what we would expect. It was a little bit soft in January and February, and we were a bit worried about the visibility. In other words, we felt we do a little bit better than we did. We felt we do a little better than we did. But we came to March and we felt that visibility was excellent. So that's -- oh, yes, on the AWS and the cloud and that question, I mean, I realized that a lot can say and we discuss the stuff a lot internally. But when we look at the installed base and the customers and the opportunities, we see a lot with things like our WAP product, our APM product that I actually get 3 examples in fact, of that type of thing. So there are definitely opportunities there as well. But we've seen new business opportunities, where a fairly big companies where we had no presence and we managed to get into that company via AWS Marketplace interestingly enough. And obviously, we feel good about the whole hybrid side of things, especially going to be more and more focused on orchestration and areas like that. Having said all that, I do still think that it's been causing causing delay in spending overall. We also see some partnership ops -- opportunities with companies like Microsoft and Amazon, or AWS, in terms of working with them on enterprise customers. And we had one very good example of that. I mentioned the banking company, where that was an example of a partnership. Yes, I think it's early days. I mean, it's not that we -- we don't look at the pipeline right now and say, "Oh! my God, this is shrinking because of Amazon." We don't see that or because of the public cloud. There's no doubt in my mind, we probably don't get some business we've got before of a start-up company that go straight to the public cloud and maybe just instead of buying equipment just run some software, that software could well be ours. But it's not critical. Yes, the major concern it gives us right now is, is it causing delays and then from an opportunity perspective, how can we maximize our product on those public clouds and by partnering with the cloud vendors.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Paul, you're asking about the virtual editions in the pricing. And essentially, at our entry-level hardware systems, you do see parity on the gross margin dollar still. So it's not quite the same price wise, but it's equivalent on the gross marg
componenttext: And then, Paul, you're asking about the virtual editions in the pricing. And essentially, at our entry-level hardware systems, you do see parity on the gross margin dollar still. So it's not quite the same price wise, but it's equivalent on the gross margin dollars. And we're still seeing the deal sizes aren't necessarily smaller because usually, when they're buying virtual editions, they're deploying them on a more horizontal type of architecture. So they need more versions of it. So we're still in that kind of position. Some of the things I'd highlight though was we're looking at new licensing models specifically for the cloud. So bring your own license or you can take the VE and move it as you want to. Enterprise license agreements. If they want a license in large scale, we'll do an enterprise license agreement. And I think where we're coming out with a 40-gig VE. In an NFV environment, you may see that as well, where we do a lot of larger to enterprise-type license agreements, and then we'll see how that works out at discounting. And then we do offer on a utility basis, on AWS, the ability to pull out your credit card and license our virtual edition. So we'll continue to be looking at those business models to evolve them to the needs of our customers.
