headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to see if you could talk a little bit more about what's going on with the public and hybrid cloud. It's my impression that the press release and your prepared comments talk more about public cloud as an opportunity than you have in the past, and
componenttext: I wanted to see if you could talk a little bit more about what's going on with the public and hybrid cloud. It's my impression that the press release and your prepared comments talk more about public cloud as an opportunity than you have in the past, and I imagine part of this is the introduction of the shuttle series. So 2 things I'm trying to understand. One is public cloud, a sense of how that's percent of your business or the trends there. And then in terms of kind of hybrid applications, how much of the sales are made to the public cloud versus the enterprise customer, if we could understand the mechanics of a hybrid transaction.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It's still a very small number. We don't give the exact percentage. It's still a small number from a revenue perspective. I mean it really is the infancy in terms of the opportunity. However, we understand it's very real. The reason you're hearing
componenttext: Right. It's still a very small number. We don't give the exact percentage. It's still a small number from a revenue perspective. I mean it really is the infancy in terms of the opportunity. However, we understand it's very real. The reason you're hearing more about it is that we're doing good penetration with our security products like APM and the WAF. Our orchestration is becoming more important. When we've seen pieces of application move from a customer, say, to a public cloud, then as I mentioned we're seeing things like programmability and iRules still being just as critical. It's areas like that but we're talking -- we're still talking fairly small, really fair -- small numbers. The other thing is that both in the hybrid cloud and in the public cloud environment, remember, we're focused on the Fortune 500 customers, we're about 80% of the Fortune 500. They are asking us to help them from an architecture and an implementation perspective, so that gives us an advantage in that area as well.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: And the mechanics of the transaction, is it generally to the enterprise customer rather than the public cloud entity?

componenttextpreview: Well, there's more than one road to market. Most of what I was just describing there was involving the enterprise customer, but we also have our products available on the public clouds that can be rented, purchased. Again, that's small numbers, fast growi
componenttext: Well, there's more than one road to market. Most of what I was just describing there was involving the enterprise customer, but we also have our products available on the public clouds that can be rented, purchased. Again, that's small numbers, fast growing but very small numbers. But that's also important to us and it will be getting more important over the next few years.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: And the shuttle series is an enabler for more of this is my understanding.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Karl. Yes, I mean the shuttle series is designed with future proofing in mind to support these cloud-based applications and the hybrid specifically to be able to connect seamlessly between private, traditional data center and cloud-based appl
componenttext: Yes. This is Karl. Yes, I mean the shuttle series is designed with future proofing in mind to support these cloud-based applications and the hybrid specifically to be able to connect seamlessly between private, traditional data center and cloud-based applications. And we do that obviously through all the programmability that we provide but also we have specialized programmable hardware that allows us to effectively create these connections and essentially, optimize these connections between these private, public and the data center.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Balaji on behalf of Simona. I wanted to touch on the stand-alone security products that you recently introduced. I know it's early days, but what sort of interests are you seeing there? And then maybe even what the rationale was for introducing st
componenttext: This is Balaji on behalf of Simona. I wanted to touch on the stand-alone security products that you recently introduced. I know it's early days, but what sort of interests are you seeing there? And then maybe even what the rationale was for introducing stand-alone products now since you haven't done this in the past?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there's a few reasons for us to go off and drive towards this, and one was that we wanted to -- today, essentially we have an ADC platform that provides best-of-breed security, especially application security identity access management, but it doe
componenttext: Yes. So there's a few reasons for us to go off and drive towards this, and one was that we wanted to -- today, essentially we have an ADC platform that provides best-of-breed security, especially application security identity access management, but it doesn't necessarily lend itself well to going and targeting specific areas within the security buying centers. And what we wanted to do is create a differentiated offering that allowed us to go out and drive essentially towards these to better position ourselves with the security buying centers in the enterprise's cloud, et cetera. And so we picked essentially functions, if you will, or products that our field had been asking us for to differentiate and we thought that there was a broad -- there'd be broad adoption of. And so one of the ones we picked up, that we went after first, DDoS. We have a best-of-breed solution there. We do things both at Layer 4, network-based, volumetric style attacks, and we also do things at the application layer. And it's very differentiated that we tie these together seamlessly. Another big area has been SSL intercept. And as John mentioned in his script, we've had customers that can implement certain parts of this functionality natively on our ADC platforms but it requires a lot of programming, iRules, things like that, to actually get that to work. So what we wanted to do is package that, make it easy to deploy and use and have differentiations specifically for that and then charge separately for that. And the same thing with the carrier-grade firewall that we had announced. And this is just the first start of kind of a line of products. We'll have other ones that we produce as time goes on. As part of this, we have a whole laundry list of things, and we'll have specific platforms and branding and everything else that, that will go out as part of that. You'll see that announced later this year.

componenttext: Yes. And on the service provider question, no. If you look at, especially Tier 1s that I mentioned, we won Gi firewalls project. headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch on the software topic. John, I think you said 38% of product revenue was software on the quarter. That's up from about 1/3 quarter-on-quarter which is a big move and I assume it's a lot year-on-year too. The press release says a 4x perfo
componenttext: I wanted to touch on the software topic. John, I think you said 38% of product revenue was software on the quarter. That's up from about 1/3 quarter-on-quarter which is a big move and I assume it's a lot year-on-year too. The press release says a 4x performance improvement and virtual editions to be released in the December quarter. So how do you get a 4x performance improvement? And what's the percent mix look like near the medium term with software?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take that. This is Karl. I'll take that question. On the 4x, it's a lot of really good engineering. Now, we've done lot of work on the guts of our system in our software to really enable ourselves to run at the these higher performance rates. And so
componenttext: I'll take that. This is Karl. I'll take that question. On the 4x, it's a lot of really good engineering. Now, we've done lot of work on the guts of our system in our software to really enable ourselves to run at the these higher performance rates. And so we've been working on this for quite some time. Like I said earlier in the call, we demoed with Intel on some of their newer CPUs essentially in earlier version of our 100-gig VE that will be coming out. So when we talk about 100 gig, obviously, in terms of throughput and performance, we put some bounds essentially on what functions are actually running on that. We're not going to run a database at 100 gig on the thing. But we are running traffic and a lot of our major functionality at that performance level.

componenttext: We'll see. We'll see. I mean, remember, we're about to introduce the shuttle series and that could have a -- actually, it could change that percentage. We'll see, I mean, that's going to be our goal. I mean, one of the things I've mentioned a number of times is that we have a large installed base. I mentioned this in a couple of the conference calls. We have a large installed base of products that are under contract more than 5 years old. And, for example, greater than 5 years old, we have 42,000 systems that are greater than 5 years old. To put that in perspective, when we did the last product refresh, we had 25,000 that were more than 5 years old. So we think that's an opportunity, and that could affect that percentage one way or the other, but the whole goal is to be successful in software and to drive the shuttle series as much as possible.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John El
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions]. I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may now begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vince, and welcome all of you on the line to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Vince, and welcome all of you on the line to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our exec team, including Ben Gibson, Chief Marketing Officer; and Ryan Kearny, Chief Technical Officer, are on hand to answer questions following their prepared comments.
If you have any follow-up questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571. A copy of today's press release is available on our website at f5.com. In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast from the Events page -- Events Calender page of our website through January 25. At 4:30 p.m. today until midnight Pacific Time, October 27, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (866) 479-8682 or (203) 369-1542.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements, which include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements.
Factors that may affect our results are summarized in our quarterly press release, described in detail in our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call.
Before we begin the call, I want to remind you that we are holding our 2016 Analyst Investor Meeting at the Intercontinental Chicago Magnificent Mile Hotel on Thursday, November 17 from 8 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. If you plan to attend the meeting, you can register online from the link on our IR Events Calendar page for November 17. For those who are unable to join us in person, the meeting will be webcast live, and a replay of the webcast will be available through January 25, 2017.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. F5 closed fiscal 2016 with a strong finish. Both revenue and earnings for the fourth quarter fiscal 2016 came in above our guidance as a result of solid year-over-year sales growth in the Americas, APAC and Japan and healthy demand for ou
componenttext:
Thank you, John. F5 closed fiscal 2016 with a strong finish. Both revenue and earnings for the fourth quarter fiscal 2016 came in above our guidance as a result of solid year-over-year sales growth in the Americas, APAC and Japan and healthy demand for our existing products ahead of our appliance refresh that begun rolling out in mid-September.
Revenue of $525.3 million was up 6% from the prior quarter and 5% year-over-year and above our guided range of $515 million to $525 million. GAAP EPS was $1.64 per share, above our guidance of $1.44 to $1.47 per share. Non-GAAP EPS of $2.11 also exceeded our guidance of $1.92 to $1.95 per share. Q4 product revenue of $253 million, up 9% from Q3 and down 2% from Q4 of last year, represented 48% of revenue. Service revenue of $272.4 million increased 3% sequentially, 12% year-over-year and accounted for 52% of revenue. On a regional basis, Americas revenue grew 5% year-over-year and represented 58% of total revenue. EMEA revenue grew 4% year-over-year and accounted for 23% of overall revenue. APAC revenue, which accounted for 14% of the total, increased 1% year-over-year. And Japan at 4% of total revenue was up 13% from a year ago. 
During the quarter, enterprise customers represented 64% of total sales. Service providers accounted for 18%, and government sales were 18%, including 10% from U.S. federal.
In Q4, we had 3 greater than 10% distributors: Westcon, which accounted for 18% of total revenue; Ingram Micro, which accounted for 15.2%; and Avnet at 12.5%. 
Continuing down the income statement. GAAP gross margin in Q4 was 83.8%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 85.2%. GAAP operating expenses of $277.8 million were at the low end of our $276 million to $285 million guided range. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $242.7 million. Our GAAP operating margin in Q4 was 31%, and non-GAAP operating margin was 39%. 
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the quarter was 33.1%, and our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 31.9%.
Turning to the balance sheet. In Q4, we generated $204 million in cash flow from operations, which contributed to cash and investments totaling $1.16 billion at year-end. DSO was 46 days. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $17.6 million. Inventory at the end of the quarter was $34.1 million. Deferred revenue increased 11% year-over-year to $870.2 million. 
In Q4, we repurchased approximately 1.2 million shares of our common stock at an average price of $124.31 per share for a total of $150 million. Approximately $774 million remains authorized under the current share repurchase program. And in Q4, we increased our headcount by 70 employees to 4,395. 
For the full year, revenue for fiscal 2016 was just under $2 billion, up 4% from fiscal 2015. Product revenue of $944.5 million was down 5% from the prior year and accounted for 47% of total revenue. Service revenue of $1.05 billion grew 13% during the year and represented 53% of the total. GAAP net income for fiscal 2016 was $365.9 million or $5.38 per share, and non-GAAP net income was $496.2 million or $7.30 per share. And for all of fiscal 2016, cash flow from operations totaled $712 million.
Moving on to our guidance for Q1 and our fiscal year '17 outlook. We are encouraged by increasing customer demand for all the new products we introduced in the second half of fiscal 2016, in particular for our new family of BIG-IP appliances, the Shuttle series, which we launched in September. We expect to finish the rollout of these products in November, and we anticipate a steady ramp in sales as they replace sales of our existing appliance family over the course of this year. 
As we look to Q1, we expect to see the normal seasonality that accompanies the start of a new fiscal year. In addition, we anticipate a continued challenging sales environment within EMEA over the short term, particularly in the U.K., which we have also factored in when assessing our revenue expectations for Q1.
With that in mind, for the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we are targeting revenue in a range of $510 million to $520 million. We expect the GAAP gross margins at or around 83%, including approximately $5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2.7 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets.
Non-GAAP gross margins are anticipated at or around 84.5%. We estimate GAAP operating expense of $285 million to $294 million, including approximately $38 million of stock-based compensation expense and $0.8 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets.
We anticipate a GAAP effective tax rate of 33% for the quarter and a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 31.5%. Our Q1 GAAP earnings target is $1.40 to $1.43 per share. Our non-GAAP earnings target is $1.92 to $1.95 per share. We believe we will generate cash flow from operations at or around $200 million, and we plan to increase our headcount by 60 to 80 employees during the quarter.
Looking out to the fiscal year ahead, our general planning assumptions and expectations are as follows. From the base of Q1, we anticipate sequential revenue growth throughout the year with a strong second half of the fiscal year. We anticipate that non-GAAP gross margins will remain in the 84% to 85% range. We expect non-GAAP operating margins in the mid-30s range for the first half of the year and increasing to the upper 30s range for the second half. Stock-based compensation is anticipated to be in the range of $175 million to $185 million for the year. Capital expenditures are expected to range from $15 million to $20 million per quarter for ongoing infrastructure investments and facilities expansions.
And finally, we expect our effective tax rates to average approximately 32% to 34% on a GAAP basis and 31% to 33% on a non-GAAP basis for the year. As John mentioned, our Analyst Investor Meeting will be November 17 in Chicago. We hope you can join us for this in-depth look at our business and our plans for fiscal 2017 and beyond.
With that, I will turn the call over to John McAdam.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I will discuss the Q4 results in some detail and then outline the progress we have made during fiscal 2016 towards our goal of returning product revenue growth in fiscal 2017. Overall, I was very pleased with th
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I will discuss the Q4 results in some detail and then outline the progress we have made during fiscal 2016 towards our goal of returning product revenue growth in fiscal 2017. Overall, I was very pleased with the F5 team's fiscal Q4 performance, including record revenues of $525 million, record cash from operations of $204 million and record profitability with 39% non-GAAP operating margin. 
Many of the process systems and training investments that we made throughout the year and our go-to-market engine together with the significant addition of new sales and marketing leadership talent began to bear fruit in fiscal Q4. I'm especially encouraged by the improvement in sales execution last quarter from the Americas region, which returned to year-over-year sales growth for the first time in several quarters. I view this as a significant milestone on our path to delivering consistent product revenue growth. I was also happy with the results of our Japan and our Asia Pacific regions, which both fell year-over-year sales bookings growth in the quarter and the entire fiscal year. 
Sales bookings in EMEA, however, were again down year-over-year, driven by weak sales in the U.K. Once again, our Services business delivered strong results and an excellent profitability with year-over-year revenue growth of 12%. As well as providing world class customer satisfaction, our service business has been crucial to our profitability throughout fiscal 2016.
We believe that our several emerging market conditions that have increased the appeal of our products with enterprise and service provider customers in Q4. Firstly, customers are increasingly leveraging our products, not only for native security features but also for the ability of our products to orchestrate and Intercept SSL traffic rules. Hackers today are more often leveraging SSL traffic for malware delivery thereby making the F5 SSL Orchestrator and inspection capabilities more and more relevant. For example, a $5 billion health care organization deployed F5's iHealth application and in so doing determined that 93% of its data center traffic was encrypted and that its existing perimeter firewalls were being defeated by a flood of malicious and nonmalicious traffic. The ultimate resolution included deploying an F5 ee-based SSL solution, working in tandem with a Cisco intrusion prevention offering. This collaborative SSL filtration solution was repeated more than a dozen times this quarter in several large global enterprises.
Similarly, we experienced real traction with our anti-fraud WebSafe platforms in Q4. We believe this reflects both the increasing sophistication of bad actors focused on credential theft as well as the explosion of SSL traffic in the transport of the email and other enterprise and public messaging applications. Our WebSafe product is very effective over SSL encrypted traffic, giving F5 very strong competitive differentiation with these solutions. We had a large win in Q4 with an Australian bank who leveraged our WebSafe and mobile safe anti-fraud capabilities to facilitate the protection of 10 million domestic and international banking customers. The F5 solution provides a client risk private cloud capability to the bank, which uniquely met the requirements of the ever-growing mobile banking clientele. 
Our second emerging trend is the growth opportunity we are experiencing with customers provisioning our proxy-based security solutions to deploy a consistent security stack and security policies across on-premise, off-premise and public cloud infrastructure such as AWS and Microsoft Azure. A multinational airline was suffering from brute force attacks against its web-based and private cloud assets. This customer leveraged a combination of our ASM and server line WAF as a service offerings to mitigate unwanted and help them meet end customer service delivery expectations. This solution provided a set of IT administration abilities across its hybrid, public and private cloud environments thus reducing management complexity and total cost of ownership.
Similarly, 2 different banks in our Asia Pacific data deployed BIG-IP ASM modules within the AWS environment to facilitate a public cloud migration of several customer-facing Internet banking sites. Our solution allowed both banks to duplicate both their ASM functionality and their home built library of fire rules that they have optimized in their own premise data center for use in the public cloud. As we gain more and more experience of customers using F5 solutions to move their apps and what goes to public and private cloud architectures, we are convinced that this is yet a third market trend with significant opportunities for F5. Within our existing customers -- I'm sorry, when our existing customers initiate lift and shift programs to move applications to the public cloud, we continue to view rich F5 ADC functionality such as programmability via iRules as critical for application optimization and application security. For example, an international provider of SaaS-based workforce automation solutions leveraged a virtualization traffic management capabilities and AWS environment to activate remote instances of the product in Canada, Australia and the United kingdom. Working together, AWS and F5 helped the customer emulate the traffic management protocol and reuse the on-premise configuration details they had optimized and over time. The resulting solution greatly reduced the latency of the international customers have been experiencing when accessing the application remotely. This trend was reinforced when our U.S.-based provider of entertainment media and streaming content deployed their ADC solution in the Amazon Web Services environment. Our cloud-based solution allows for rapid activation of additional streaming sessions during on-demand style broadcast when subscriber demand significantly exceeded expectations. The content of these events is primarily delivered by the customer's private cloud. However, this joint F5 and AWS solution provided for a standby capacity leveraging a hybrid cloud architecture.
From a product perspective, we delivered on our goal to commence shipments of a new range of appliances in Q4. This new product lineup, known internally as the Shuttle series, is perhaps the most comprehensive range of new products we have delivered to the market. We started shipping the high-end products in the final weeks of the quarter, and we expect to have the entire product range available by the end of November. As I have mentioned before, the Shuttle series is more than a simple product line upgrade. We believe that the Shuttle series the world's most programmable cloud-ready ADC. The Shuttle series provides the agility that Dev Ops organization demand together with the scale, security, investment protection that our traditional customers have long enjoyed.
In our quarterly conference call last January when we announced our Q1 results, I gave a high-level be of the significant array of new products we had in the road map for delivery in fiscal 2016. The Shuttle series capped a tremendous suite of product introductions in fiscal 2016, which will provide solid business drivers in the current fiscal year, enabling the F5 team to achieve our goal of delivering product revenue growth throughout the year. We saw a very good traction in sales of our new 100 gig blade last quarter, and it was exciting to see a significant number of these sales taking advantage of the 100 gig blades world-class performance to enhance solutions like the G.I. firewall. Security, G.I. line consolidation, NFV solutions, traffic and TCP optimization continue to be successfully focused for F5 in the service provider market. 
Our vast array of new products, including the Shuttle series, the SSL Orchestrator, the DDoS Defender, mobile safe, iApps LX, BIG-IQ and under iWorkflow orchestration engine as well as our upcoming TMOS 13.0 release all further support our efforts and enable our customers to efficiently migrate their apps to private and public cloud architectures.
As far as fiscal 2017 Q1 outlook is concerned, Andy discussed our high level financial views of fiscal 2017 and indicated that we expect to deliver revenues in the range of $510 million to $520 million in the first quarter. I believe that F5 is very well positioned moving into fiscal 2017 to take advantage of the new products and business drivers as well as the new opportunities, including the explosion of SSL encrypted traffic. Customer requirements to have consistent security policies across on-premise and public clouds and the move of application workflows to private and public cloud architectures. We will be presenting our strategy in detail at the November Analyst Investor Conference. We have a lot to cover that day, including details on our strategy and road map on several topics. For example, we will present our plans and progress on Dev Ops-centric architectures, including micro services, OpenStack, orchestration and visibility and analytics. And I look forward to seeing you at the event.
In conclusion, I'd like to thank the entire F5 team, our partners and customers for the support last quarter. And with that, I will now hand the call over for Q&A.

componenttext: Just 2 if I could. First, if we could just touch on Europe. It sounds like you've had some really good sales execution in the U.S. market. If anything that could be done differently in Europe or is it just really too much macro that's going on there that might make that a little bit more challenging? And then secondly, could you just update us on how trends for stand-alone security products and the software offerings trended in the quarter and the outlook for -- into next fiscal year?

componenttext: Okay. On EMEA, first of all, and talk about EMEA just Europe because that's what the organization. First of all, we've had strong management in EMEA for a long time, and they actually had an excellent fiscal 2015 but definitely, 2016 was probably problematic in some areas. I really believe that macro was definitely involved in the U.K. issue. And one of the things that's probably unique to F5 more than a lot of other companies is that if you look at our major accounts regions, the financial vector is very, very important in that region. And frankly, that was a tough market after the Brexit announcement where they seem to be taking some time to make up their mind as to where they will deploy their money moving forward. So having said that, you always look at execution, and we continue to do that. I think it was more macro. In terms of the stand-alone product, I mean SSL, you had me talking about SSL and Orchestration and Intercept. That's -- and also DDoS, I mean they're the first 2 solutions that we come out with. We feel very, very good about the trajectory of that solution base. We're going to be talking a lot more about this in November, and you'll hear us talking about product additions in that area. I don't want to get into it now. It's not appropriate, but you'll hear us talk into that. I think it will increase the opportunity in 2017 and also more functionality as well. But we think because of our SSL expertise, we are really, really well positioned to take the opportunity. Andy, do you want to mention anything about service chaining now it's a unique capability for us?

componenttext: I guess I had a quick technology question and then maybe a question on the numbers looking into '17. So on that tech question, Ryan, there's a lot of -- a lot of people are looking at visualizing guys, and they really like the fact that the software had a very small footprint, it's virtualizable. And you guys I know you've talked about this from time to time but I just wondered if you could update us on where you are with shrinking the footprint of the software so that it really lends itself to a virtualized environment and automated environment for out new and so on. So if you could just talk about that and then I'll just follow up after you answer with the financial questions.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. The footprint of software and virtualized ADC functionality, it's very important to be smaller, more agile, more flexible in these new cloud environments, both public and private cloud. To put a significant amount of investment into this
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. The footprint of software and virtualized ADC functionality, it's very important to be smaller, more agile, more flexible in these new cloud environments, both public and private cloud. To put a significant amount of investment into this actually over the last few quarters will continue to do so actually, including smaller versions within Amazon, more -- smaller versions actually helping us increase the density of these solutions within hardware platforms and stuff like that. It's also not just a smaller footprint, but it's faster boot times. It's easier licensing. It's more service level APIs for programmability and orchestration. So in general, getting lighter, faster is definitely part of it, but fitting into these new orchestration environments and increasing capacity and density is also critical. So it's a big focus area.

componenttext: Yes. Actually, if you look at the last couple of years, we've given the same sort of guidance rolling into the new fiscal year where we've said, "Look, we see seasonality in Q1 sometimes rolling into Q2 and then we strengthen in the back half."  And historically, when we've tried to maintain operating margin at 2 consistent of a level throughout the year, it's hurt us when our primary investment vehicle is headcount and the slow things way down and then try to catch it up again. So I think it was our did in fiscal '14. We went to this mid-30s in the first  half to allow us to keep investing and then drives trend through the back half of the back of strong revenue. And that's what we're laying out again for execution for this year.

And then as the classic lift and shift capability that we've seen where we've seen a very, very, very almost 100% success rate where customers lift and shift solutions or apps and move them over but they want to use a security products, so they want to use iRules. And again, we think that's a big opportunity we're going to be partnering with is we're and AWS for those types of opportunities. And I'm not going to be specific numbers. We've also seen examples where, for example, our WAP that we put on as [indiscernible]  And cloud gets like a complete new business opportunity where we've seen that as well. I think that's covering most of what you asked. It's a pretty broad question. But generally, we feel quite good now that this whole move, this trend is an opportunity for all because of richness in our software and our security portfolio and our application optimization portfolio.

componenttext: Really, when you look at our margin profile, the gross margin, it was really driven by services on a couple of fronts. One, we're seeing higher gross margins from our consulting business. Efficiency is just over all with technology that we're using for just higher productivity call avoidance, those types of things. And then our hiring was a little behind which drove it up as well. Gross margin on the product side was actually pretty consistent quarter-over-quarter. So in our guidance, you see that we pulled it back little bit, and that's because we'll probably catch up on the hiring side as we drive through Q1. And then in terms of the profile as it relates to the new product introductions, they're going to be pretty consistent. We're still in the position that we are able to price to margin and we do that in driving value, and we see that in the consistent -- consistency in the product margin we've seen for really years.

We actually talked a lot of customer example showing the opposite rate where it was a tailwind, and what you've seen is that tailwind getting stronger in Q4.

componenttext: And when you look at the cloud, how does the business model change for existing customers? Meaning, if today you charge certain price on the product and then you have maintenance revenues, what happens when you migrate to the cloud for the same customer?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's a complicated question in the sense it depends on the architecture the customer goes for. So example, a customer may move applications that don't have any of this in front of them that's an opportunity for us. A customer when we moves applicati
componenttext: And that's a complicated question in the sense it depends on the architecture the customer goes for. So example, a customer may move applications that don't have any of this in front of them that's an opportunity for us. A customer when we moves applications to see a public cloud may want to do more horizontal scaling because it's a software that type shift, and that's an opportunity. In fact, we talked about that before where when we see the EMEA type solution, we tend to see as much revenue because it's not a vertical scalability as far as another one instead of VIPRION sitting in front of 100 apps, you have one app, one image of VE per app. So it's quite a complicated scenario. But we feel good about it. Everything we've seen tells us it's an opportunity. The other thing we can talk about when we do that is adding security. Security when you move to the cloud is critical. So the chance was adding more fortunate a module perspective is also good.

componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to the F5 Networks Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2016 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also, today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Mr. John Eldridge, Director of Investor Relations. Sir, you may now begin.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Vince, and welcome all of you on the line to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Vince, and welcome all of you on the line to our conference call for the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2016. John McAdam, President and CEO; and Andy Reinland, Executive VP and CFO, will be the speakers on today's call. Other members of our exec team, including Ben Gibson, Chief Marketing Officer; and Ryan Kearny, Chief Technical Officer, are on hand to answer questions following their prepared comments.
If you have any follow-up questions after the call, please direct them to me at (206) 272-6571. A copy of today's press release is available on our website at f5.com. In addition, you can access an archived version of today's live webcast from the Events page -- Events Calender page of our website through January 25. From 4:30 p.m. today until 5 p.m. Pacific Time, October 27, you can also listen to a telephone replay at (866) 479-8682 or (203) 369-1542.
During today's call, our discussion will contain forward-looking statements, which include words such as believe, anticipate, expect and target. These forward-looking statements involve uncertainties and risks that may cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements.
Factors that may affect our results are summarized in our quarterly release, described in detail on our SEC filings. Please note that F5 has no duty to update any information presented in this call.
Before we begin the call, I want to remind you that we are holding our 2016 Analyst Investor Meeting at the InterContinental Chicago Magnificent Mile Hotel on Thursday, November 17 from 8 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. If you plan to attend the meeting, you can register online from the link on our IR Events Calendar page for November 17. For those who aren't able to join us in person, the meeting will be webcast live, and a replay of the webcast will be available through January 25, 2017.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andy Reinland.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. F5 closed fiscal 2016 with a strong finish. Both revenue and earnings for the fourth quarter fiscal 2016 came in above our guidance as a result of solid year-over-year sales growth in the Americas, APAC and Japan and healthy demand for ou
componenttext:
Thank you, John. F5 closed fiscal 2016 with a strong finish. Both revenue and earnings for the fourth quarter fiscal 2016 came in above our guidance as a result of solid year-over-year sales growth in the Americas, APAC and Japan and healthy demand for our existing products ahead of our appliance refresh that began rolling out in mid-September.
Revenue of $525.3 million was up 6% from the prior quarter and 5% year-over-year and above our guided range of $515 million to $525 million. GAAP EPS was $1.64 per share, above our guidance of $1.44 to $1.47 per share. Non-GAAP EPS of $2.11 also exceeded our guidance of $1.92 to $1.95 per share. Q4 product revenue of $253 million, up 9% from Q3 and down 2% from Q4 of last year, represented 48% of revenue. Service revenue of $272.4 million increased 3% sequentially, 12% year-over-year and accounted for 52% of revenue. On a regional basis, Americas revenue grew 5% year-over-year and represented 58% of total revenue. EMEA revenue grew 4% year-over-year and accounted for 23% of overall revenue. APAC revenue, which accounted for 14% of the total, increased 1% year-over-year. And Japan at 4% of total revenue was up 13% from year ago. 
During the quarter, enterprise customers represented 64% of total sales. Service providers accounted for 18% and government sales were 18%, including 10% from U.S. federal.
In Q4, we have 3 greater than 10% distributors: Westcon, which accounted for 18% of total revenue; Ingram Micro, which accounted for 15.2%; and Avnet at 12.5%. 
Continuing down the income statement. GAAP gross margin in Q4 was 83.8%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 85.2%. GAAP operating expenses of $277.8 million were at the low end of our $276 million to $285 million guided range. Non-GAAP operating expenses were $242.7 million. Our GAAP operating margin in Q4 was 31%, and non-GAAP operating margin was 39%. 
Our GAAP effective tax rate for the quarter was 33.1%, and our non-GAAP effective tax rate was 31.9%.
Turning to the balance sheet. In Q4, we generated $204 million in cash flow from operations, which contributed to cash and investments totaling $1.16 billion at year-end. DSO was 46 days. Capital expenditures for the quarter were $17.6 million. Inventory at the end of the quarter was $34.1 million. Deferred revenue increased 11% year-over-year to $870.2 million. 
In Q4, we repurchased approximately 1.2 million shares of our common stock at an average price of $124.31 per share for a total of $150 million. Approximately $774 million remains authorized under the current share repurchase program. And in Q4, we increased our headcount by 70 employees to 4,395. 
For the full year, revenue for fiscal 2016 was just under $2 billion, up 4% from fiscal 2015. Product revenue of $944.5 million was down 5% from the prior year and accounted for 47% of total revenue. Service revenue of $1.05 billion grew 13% during the year and represented 53% of the total. GAAP net income for fiscal 2016 was $365.9 million or $5.38 per share, and non-GAAP net income was $496.2 million or $7.30 per share. And for all of fiscal 2016, cash flow from operations totaled $712 million.
Moving on to our guidance for Q1 and our fiscal year '17 outlook. We are encouraged by increasing customer demand for all the new products we introduced in the second half of fiscal 2016, in particular for our new family of BIG-IP appliances, the Shuttle series, which we launched in September. We expect to finish the rollout of these products in November, and we anticipate a steady ramp in sales as they replace sales of our existing appliance family over the course of this year. 
As we look to Q1, we expect to see the normal seasonality that accompanies the start of a new fiscal year. In addition, we anticipate a continued challenging sales environment within EMEA over the short term, particularly in the U.K., which we have also factored in when assessing our revenue expectations for Q1.
With that in mind, for the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we are targeting revenue in a range of $510 million to $520 million. We expect GAAP gross margins at or around 83%, including approximately $5 million of stock-based compensation expense and $2.7 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets.
Non-GAAP gross margins are anticipated at or around 84.5%. We estimate GAAP operating expense of $285 million to $294 million, including approximately $38 million of stock-based compensation expense and $0.8 million in amortization of purchased intangible assets.
We anticipate a GAAP effective tax rate of 33% for the quarter and a non-GAAP effective tax rate of 31.5%. Our Q1 GAAP earnings target is $1.40 to $1.43 per share. Our non-GAAP earnings target is $1.92 to $1.95 per share. We believe we will generate cash flow from operations at or around $200 million, and we plan to increase our headcount by 60 to 80 employees during the quarter.
Looking out to the fiscal year ahead, our general planning assumptions and expectations are as follows. From the base of Q1, we anticipate sequential revenue growth throughout the year with the strong second half of the fiscal year. We anticipate that non-GAAP gross margins will remain in the 84% to 85% range. We expect non-GAAP operating margins in the mid-30s range for the first half of the year and increasing to the upper 30s range over the second half. Stock-based compensation is anticipated to be in the range of $175 million to $185 million for the year. Capital expenditures are expected to range from $15 million to $20 million per quarter for ongoing infrastructure investments and facilities expansions.
And finally, we expect our effective tax rates to average approximately 32% to 34% on a GAAP basis and 31% to 33% on a non-GAAP basis for the year. As John mentioned, our Analyst Investor Meeting will be November 17 in Chicago. We hope you can join us for this in-depth look at our business and our plans for fiscal 2017 and beyond.
With that, I will turn the call over to John McAdam.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I will discuss the Q4 results in some detail and then outline the progress we have made during fiscal 2016 towards our goal of returning product revenue growth in fiscal 2017. Overall, I was very pleased with th
componenttext:
Thanks, Andy, and good afternoon, everyone. I will discuss the Q4 results in some detail and then outline the progress we have made during fiscal 2016 towards our goal of returning product revenue growth in fiscal 2017. Overall, I was very pleased with the F5 team's fiscal Q4 performance, including record revenues of $525 million, record cash from operations of $204 million and record profitability with 39% non-GAAP operating margin. 
Many of the process, systems and training investments that we made throughout the year and our go-to-market engine, together with the significant addition of new sales and marketing leadership talent, began to bear fruit in fiscal Q4. I'm especially encouraged by the improvement in sales execution last quarter from the Americas region, which returned to year-over-year sales growth for the first time in several quarters. I view this as a significant milestone on our path to delivering consistent product revenue growth. I was also happy with the results of our Japan and our Asia Pacific regions, which both delivered year-over-year sales bookings growth for the quarter and the entire fiscal year. 
Sales bookings in EMEA, however, were again down year-over-year, driven by weak sales in the U.K. Once again, our Services business delivered strong results and excellent profitability with year-over-year revenue growth of 12%. As well as providing world class customer satisfaction, our service business has been crucial to our profitability throughout fiscal 2016.
We believe that several emerging market conditions that have increased the appeal of our products with enterprise and service provider customers in Q4. Firstly, customers are increasingly leveraging our products, not only for native security features but also for the ability of our products to orchestrate and intercept SSL traffic rules. Hackers today are more often leveraging SSL traffic for malware delivery thereby making the F5 SSL orchestration and inspection capabilities more and more relevant. For example, a $5 billion health care organization deployed F5's iHealth application and in so doing determined that 93% of its data center traffic was encrypted and that its existing perimeter firewalls were being defeated by a flood of malicious and nonmalicious traffic. The ultimate resolution included deploying an F5 VE-based SSL solution, working in tandem with the Cisco FirePOWER intrusion prevention offering. This collaborative SSL filtration solution was repeated more than a dozen times this quarter in several large global enterprises.
Similarly, we experienced real traction with our anti-fraud WebSafe platforms in Q4. We believe this reflects both the increasing sophistication of bad actors focused on credential theft as well as the explosion of SSL traffic in the transport of the email and other enterprise and public messaging applications. Our WebSafe product is very effective over SSL encrypted traffic, giving F5 very strong competitive differentiation with these solutions. We had a large win in Q4 with an Australian bank who leveraged our WebSafe and MobileSafe anti-fraud capabilities to facilitate the protection of 10 million domestic and international banking customers. The F5 solution provides a clientless private cloud capability to the bank, which uniquely met the requirements of their ever-growing mobile banking clientele. 
Our second emerging trend is the growth opportunity we are experiencing with customers provisioning our proxy-based security solutions to deploy a consistent security stack and security policies across on-premise, off-premise and public cloud infrastructure such as AWS and Microsoft Azure. A multinational airline was suffering from brute force attacks against its web-based and private cloud assets. This customer leveraged a combination of our ASM WAF and Silverline WAF as a service offerings to mitigate unwanted package stores and help them meet end customer service delivery expectations. This solution provided a set of IT administration abilities across its hybrid, public and private cloud environments thus reducing management complexity and total cost of ownership.
Similarly, 2 different banks in Asia Pacific [indiscernible] deployed BIG-IP ASM modules within the AWS environment to facilitate a public cloud migration of several customer-facing Internet banking sites. Our solution allowed both banks to duplicate both their ASM functionality and their homebuilt library of iRules that they had optimized in their own-premise data center for use in the public cloud. As we gain more and more experience of customers using F5 solutions to move their apps and workloads to public and private cloud architectures, we are convinced that this is yet a third market trend with significant opportunities for F5. Within our existing customers -- I'm sorry, when our existing customers initiate lift and shift programs to move applications to the public cloud, they continue to view rich F5 ADC functionality such as programmability via iRules as critical for application optimization and application security. For example, an international provider of SaaS-based workforce automation solutions leveraged our virtualization traffic management capabilities in AWS environment to activate remote instances of the product in Canada, Australia and the United kingdom. Working together, AWS and F5 helped the customer emulate the traffic management protocol and reuse the on-premise configuration details they had optimized and harden over time. The resulting solution greatly reduced the latency that the international customers have been experiencing when accessing the application remotely. This trend was further reinforced when our U.S.-based provider of entertainment media and streaming content deployed our ADC solution in the Amazon Web Services environment. Our cloud-based solution allow for rapid activation of additional streaming sessions during on-demand style broadcast when subscriber demand significantly exceeded expectations. The contents of these events is primarily delivered by the customers private cloud. However, this joint F5 and AWS solution provided for a standby capacity leveraging a hybrid cloud architecture.
From a product perspective, we delivered on our goal to commence shipments of a new range of appliances in Q4. This new product lineup, known internally as the Shuttle series, is perhaps the most comprehensive range of new products we have delivered to the market. We started shipping the high-end products in the final weeks of the quarter, and we expect to have the entire product range available by the end of November. As I have mentioned before, the Shuttle series is more than a simple product line upgrade. We believe that the Shuttle series is the world's most programmable cloud-ready ADC. The Shuttle series provides the agility that Dev Ops organization demand together with the scale, security, investment protection that's our traditional customers have long enjoyed.
In our quarterly conference call last January, when we announced our Q1 results, I gave a high-level view of the significant array of new products we had in our road map for delivery in fiscal 2016. The Shuttle series capped a tremendous suite of product introductions in fiscal 2016, which will provide solid business drivers in the current fiscal year, enabling the F5 team to achieve our goal of delivering product revenue growth throughout the year. We saw a very good traction in sales of our new 100-gig blade last quarter, and it was exciting to see a significant number of these sales taking advantage of the 100-gig blade's world-class performance to enhance solutions like the Gi firewall. Security, Gi line consolidation, NFV solutions, traffic steering and TCP optimization continue to be successfully the focus for F5 in the service provider market. 
Our vast array of new products, including the Shuttle series, the SSL Orchestrator, the DDoS Defender, MobileSafe, iApps LX, BIG-IQ and iWorkflow orchestration engine as well as our upcoming TMOS 13.0 release, all further support our efforts to enable our customers to efficiently migrate their apps to private and public cloud architectures.
As far as fiscal 2017 Q1 outlook is concerned, Andy discussed our high-level financial views of fiscal 2017 and indicated that we expect to deliver revenue in the range of $510 million to $520 million in the first quarter. I believe that F5 is very well positioned moving into fiscal 2017 to take advantage of the new products and business drivers as well as the new opportunities, including the explosion of SSL encrypted traffic. Customers requirements to have consistent security policies across on-premise and public clouds and the move of application workloads to private and public cloud architectures. We will be presenting our strategy in detail at the November Analyst Investor Conference. We have a lot to cover that day, including details on our strategy and road map on several topics. For example, we will present our plans and progress on Dev Ops-centric architectures, including containerized microservices, OpenStack, orchestration and visibility and analytics. And I look forward to seeing you at the event.
In conclusion, I'd like to thank the entire F5 team, our partners and customers for the support last quarter. And with that, I will now hand the call over for Q&A.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttextpreview: Just 2, if I could. First, if we you could just touch on Europe, it sounds like you've had some really good sales execution in the U.S. market. It's anything that could be done differently in Europe or is it just really too much macro that that's going on
componenttext: Just 2, if I could. First, if we you could just touch on Europe, it sounds like you've had some really good sales execution in the U.S. market. It's anything that could be done differently in Europe or is it just really too much macro that that's going on there that might make that a little bit more challenging? And then secondly, could you just update us on how trends for stand-alone security products and the software offerings trended in the quarter and the outlook for -- into next fiscal year?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, on EMEA, first of all, and I'll talk about EMEA not just Europe because that's what the organization is. First of all, we've had strong management in EMEA for a long time, and they actually had an excellent fiscal 2015. But definitely, 2016 was
componenttext: Okay. Yes, on EMEA, first of all, and I'll talk about EMEA not just Europe because that's what the organization is. First of all, we've had strong management in EMEA for a long time, and they actually had an excellent fiscal 2015. But definitely, 2016 was probably problematic in some areas. I really believe that macro was definitely involved in the U.K. issue. And one of the things that's probably unique to F5 more than a lot of other companies is that if you look at our major accounts regions, the financial vector is very, very important in that region. And frankly, that was a tough market after the Brexit announcement where they seem to be taking some time to make up their mind as to whether they are going to deploy their money moving forward. So having said that, you always look at execution, and we continue to do that. I think it was more macro. In terms of the stand-alone product, I mean SSL, you heard me talking about SSL and orchestration and intercept. That's -- and also DDoS, I mean they're the first 2 solutions that we come out with. We feel very, very good about the trajectory of that solution base. We're going to be talking a lot more about this in November, and you'll hear us talking about product additions in that area. I don't want to get into it now. It's not appropriate, but you'll hear us talking about that. I think it will increase the opportunity in 2017 and also more functionality as well. But we think because of our SSL expertise, we are really, really well positioned to take up the opportunity. Ryan, do you want to mention anything about service chaining and how's that a unique capability for us?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Sure. I think, I mean, just to reiterate also, some of the programmability and orchestration capabilities of our product actually from a historical perspective have really lended itself very well to the new environments like NFV and service training, et cetera. And we've got a tremendous amount of good kind of response, especially through the quarter, with some of those solutions and we will continue to. So...

componenttext: Yes, and one of the things I mentioned that you may have got missed actually was, when I talked about one of the examples that use the Cisco intrusion prevention product and then there was a sentence after that talking about we've done a number of these collaborative-type solutions. headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rod Hall with JPMorgan.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I had a quick technology question and then maybe a question on the numbers looking into '17. So on that tech question, Ryan, there's a lot of -- lot of people are looking at some of these virtualized ADC guys, and they really like the fact that th
componenttext: I guess I had a quick technology question and then maybe a question on the numbers looking into '17. So on that tech question, Ryan, there's a lot of -- lot of people are looking at some of these virtualized ADC guys, and they really like the fact that the software has a very small footprint, it's virtualizable. And you guys, I know you've talked about that from time to time, but I just wonder if you could update us on where you are with shrinking the footprint of the software so that it really lend itself to a virtualized environment and automated environment for spinning up new instances of ADC and so on. So if you could just talk about that and then I'll just follow up after you answer with the financial questions.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, Absolutely. The footprint of software and virtualized ADC functionality, it's very important to be smaller, more agile, more flexible in these new cloud environments, both public and private cloud. To put a significant amount of investment into t
componenttext: Yes. No, Absolutely. The footprint of software and virtualized ADC functionality, it's very important to be smaller, more agile, more flexible in these new cloud environments, both public and private cloud. To put a significant amount of investment into this actually over the last few quarters, we will continue to do so actually, including smaller versions within Amazon, more -- smaller versions actually helping us increase the density of these solutions within hardware platforms and stuff like that. It's also not just a smaller footprint, but it's faster boot times. It's easier licensing. It's more service level APIs for programmability and orchestration. So in general, getting lighter, faster is definitely part of it, but fitting into these new orchestration environments and increasing capacity and density is also critical. So it's a big focus area.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I am probably going to say it n times in the call that again, we'll be giving this in much more detail in November, but yes, smaller, you hear us talk about microservices, elastic ADC, all that, there's a lot of things coming there, very, very cloud f
componenttext: And I am probably going to say it n times in the call that again, we'll be giving this in much more detail in November, but yes, smaller, you hear us talk about microservices, elastic ADC, all that, there's a lot of things coming there, very, very cloud friendly.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. As usual, we don't have enough patience, I guess. And then, I guess, you guys talked about this mid-30s operating margin first half of next year and then high 30s at the end of next year. Can you just walk us through -- it looks to us like yo
componenttext: Okay, great. As usual, we don't have enough patience, I guess. And then, I guess, you guys talked about this mid-30s operating margin first half of next year and then high 30s at the end of next year. Can you just walk us through -- it looks to us like you probably do high 30s in the first part of the year and I just -- what's going on with OpEx there? Are you planning to -- can you just walk us through the trajectory of OpEx for the year just so we make sure that we're thinking right on the model?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Actually, if you look at the last couple of years, we've given the same sort of guidance rolling into the new fiscal year where we've said, "Look, we see seasonality in Q1 sometimes rolling into Q2 and then we strengthen in the back half." And histor
componenttext: Yes. Actually, if you look at the last couple of years, we've given the same sort of guidance rolling into the new fiscal year where we've said, "Look, we see seasonality in Q1 sometimes rolling into Q2 and then we strengthen in the back half." And historically, when we've tried to maintain operating margin at too consistent of a level throughout the year, it hurt us when our primary investment vehicle is headcount and we slow things way down and then try to catch it up again. So I think it was started in fiscal '14. We went to this mid-30s in the first half to allow us to keep investing and then drive strength through the back half on the back of strong revenue. And that's what we're laying out again for execution for this year.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So we just think normal seasonality on the OpEx as we move through the year.

componenttext: Yes. Exactly.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a bit more of details on how your business is picking up on the cloud and like your virtual additions of your products? So my question would be first, how big is that today for you and how much, how fast is it growing? And then my second
componenttext: Could you give us a bit more of details on how your business is picking up on the cloud and like your virtual additions of your products? So my question would be first, how big is that today for you and how much, how fast is it growing? And then my second question is how much of your business in the cloud is really like new business coming from new clients and the cloud is for you actually almost like a new distribution channel. Is that allows you to address the markets you're not addressing that much before and how much of that is more like your existing clients using F5 on their own infrastructure and willing to keep a very similar framework when they go to the cloud?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. This is a pretty broad question in terms of the different areas because the answer is going to be all of the above in lot of the questions you talked about. First of all, I mean, when we talked about the 3 emerging things are happening that
componenttext: This is John. This is a pretty broad question in terms of the different areas because the answer is going to be all of the above in lot of the questions you talked about. First of all, I mean, when we talked about the 3 emerging things are happening that we feel excited about, one obviously being SSL, but the other 2 are very related to the cloud with one being -- we're seeing customers have this absolute need to have these constant security policies and processes through hybrid cloud or public cloud or private and on-premise environment, and that's a big opportunity for us. And then as the classic lift and shift capability that we've seen where we've seen a very, very, very almost 100% success rate where customers lift and shift customers, lift and shift solutions or apps and move them over, but they want to use security products, they want to use iRules. And again, we think that's a big opportunity and we're going to be partnering with Azure and AWS for those types of opportunities. And I'm not going to be specific numbers. We've also seen examples where, for example, our WAF that we put was on the Azure and cloud gets like a complete new business opportunity where we did not meet customer at all. So we've seen that as well. I think that's covering most of what you asked. That was a pretty broad question. But generally, we feel quite good now that this whole move, this trend is an opportunity for us because of richness of our software and our security portfolio and our application optimization portfolio.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the cloud is like a new channel allowing you to address like clients you are not addressing before.
componenttext: And the cloud is like a new channel allowing you to address like clients you are not addressing before.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've given -- one of the examples I gave is a customer we didn't know, we've not been selling to, buying our WAF solution off Azure. And going forward, we're going to -- one of the things we're going to be doing is increasing our inside sales organization
componenttext: I've given -- one of the examples I gave is a customer we didn't know, we've not been selling to, buying our WAF solution off Azure. And going forward, we're going to -- one of the things we're going to be doing is increasing our inside sales organization to basically focus on Silverline and doing more sales that way, which a lot of that -- by the way, a lot of that is new business when we see those customers, but also not just Silverline focus on AWS's marketplace as well as Azure as channels.

componenttext: Andy, maybe for you first here, gross margins ticked up nicely this quarter. I'm assuming that had a lot to do with software. Can you just touch on that? headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So really, when you look at our margin profile, the gross margin, it was really driven by services on a couple of fronts. One, we're seeing higher gross margins from our consulting business. Efficiency is just overall with technology that we're using
componenttext: Yes. So really, when you look at our margin profile, the gross margin, it was really driven by services on a couple of fronts. One, we're seeing higher gross margins from our consulting business. Efficiency is just overall with technology that we're using for just higher productivity call avoidance, those types of things. And then our hiring was a little behind which drove it up as well. Gross margin on the product side was actually pretty consistent quarter-over-quarter. So in our guidance, you see that we pulled it back a little bit, and that's because we'll probably catch up on the hiring side as we drive through Q1. And then in terms of the profile as it relates to the new product introductions, they're going to be pretty consistent. We're still in the position that we are able to price to margin and we do that in driving value, and we see that in the consistent -- consistency in the product margin we've seen for really years.

componenttext: So I got a question. As I think about the product cycle here, product revenue was down about 5% last year and this is the most comprehensive product refresh you had in some time. I don't know if it's bigger than buffalo jump and maybe you could comment on that. I guess what I'm looking for is maybe talking through as we think about this the installed base and you touched on it in the past, but just to refresh us the number of units up for refresh, how ASPs and deal sizes have trended relative to historicals. Any sort of input that we can take to consider and get comfortable that you can indeed grow product revenue this year? And then, why wouldn't that -- I guess the follow-up to that is just you're 6 months into this refresh and so -- or 6 weeks into this refresh. Any sort of color around how things are tracking relative to historical refreshes?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm glad you say that right. At the very end, you said 6 weeks that's a bit right, actually in the sense that we only started shipping the products, the high-end portion of the Shuttle series towards the end of the quarter, so probably 3 to -- 5 or 6
componenttext: Yes. I'm glad you say that right. At the very end, you said 6 weeks that's a bit right, actually in the sense that we only started shipping the products, the high-end portion of the Shuttle series towards the end of the quarter, so probably 3 to -- 5 or 6 weeks. We've clearly -- we've seen good traction already. And by the way and the first, it was only recently, in the last week or so, that we've been training the sales force in this and allow them to actually push up, but we've taken orders in any event. We're happy with this traction. We've seen -- remember, it's high-end products we've announced so far and then the rest of the product line we expect to be done by the end of November. There's just a lot of good reasons for it to be successful. I mean the customer base, as you asked about, more than 5 years is over 40,000 and I guess it 42,500 -- 44,000, I should say, and that's bigger than it's ever been in the product refresh before. We've got massive amount of systems available now to the sales force to highlight where these customers are, when the service contracts are up, et cetera. So they've got a lot of ammunition to be able to execute on that refresh. Was there any other questions? I think that answered the question.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I looked at my notes from last quarter and there seem to be great improvement on certain areas, and I want to focus maybe on the North American part. In your prepared remarks, you said that the North America improved. And I'm trying to understand where di
componenttext: I looked at my notes from last quarter and there seem to be great improvement on certain areas, and I want to focus maybe on the North American part. In your prepared remarks, you said that the North America improved. And I'm trying to understand where did improvement come from because last quarter, you reported on hesitancy to close some deals and push outs and migration to cloud is negatives. And this quarter, we see the opposite, and I'm trying to understand if it's an issue of products, maybe something that you have done to your sales organization that you call it execution and anything else that contributed, maybe spending cycles or anything else that contributed to this improvement in North America. So if you can discuss the factors.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And sales improved fairly significantly quarter-on-quarter. Sales, I mean I'm not just talking -- I'm not specifically talking revenue. And those sales were orders that -- some shipped in the quarter and some mostly -- some didn't. But sales increase
componenttext: Yes. And sales improved fairly significantly quarter-on-quarter. Sales, I mean I'm not just talking -- I'm not specifically talking revenue. And those sales were orders that -- some shipped in the quarter and some mostly -- some didn't. But sales increased. I mean a lot of that was execution. I mean I talked about the beginning of my script that the sales leadership that John DiLullo has brought into the company, including America sales, passion as well as some real channel expertise. We've added a whole load of new processes. But one thing you say Tal, I want to be very clear about we didn't say last quarter that we thought the cloud was a headwind. We actually talked about a lot of customer examples showing the opposite, but it was a tailwind, and what we've seen is that tailwind getting stronger in Q4.

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you look at the cloud, how does the business model change for existing customers? Meaning, if today you charge certain price on the product and then you have maintenance revenues, what happens when you migrate to the cloud for the same customer?
componenttext: And when you look at the cloud, how does the business model change for existing customers? Meaning, if today you charge certain price on the product and then you have maintenance revenues, what happens when you migrate to the cloud for the same customer?

headline: F5 Networks, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a complicated question in the sense that it depends on the architecture the customer goes for. So for example, if a customer may move applications that don't have an ADC in front of them that's an opportunity for us. A customer when we moves applic
componenttext: That's a complicated question in the sense that it depends on the architecture the customer goes for. So for example, if a customer may move applications that don't have an ADC in front of them that's an opportunity for us. A customer when we moves applications to a public cloud may want to do more horizontal scaling because it's a software that type shift and that's an opportunity. In fact, we talked about that before. When we see VE-type solutions, we tend to see as much revenue because it's not a vertical scalability as far as [indiscernible] was instead of VIPRION sitting in front of 100 apps, you have one app, one image per -- VE per app. So it's quite a complicated scenario. But we feel good about it. Everything we've seen we tell there is an opportunity. The other thing we can talk about when we do that is adding security. Security when you move to the cloud is critical. So the chance there was adding more functionality from a module perspective is also good.
